narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: rather helpful
I love this course.Strengths are professor is knowledgeable and very kind, TA is helpful, course requirement is consistent and meaningful.
This course is really disorganized...
it is simply an excellent course. I learned a lot, it is not only theoretical, but also practical.

strength: interesting topicweakness: the course is focused in designing the protocols itself, but in real world, a lot of clinical trial specialist roles cover much wider work spectrum. I think it would be helpful if the professor can add one more lecture talking about clinical trial related regulations and contemparary legal issues
Great class, homework was very helpful.

Overall, I thought the course was offered a decent overview of the fundamentals without going into a lot of detail. However links between statistics and their application could have been made clearer. In addition, the material covered in lecture could have been covered more efficiently.

This lecture instructs fundamental principles and knowledge in clinical trials. Prof. Makuch is a very experienced and prominent researcher in this area. Theory and practical examples are used in combination to illustrate. However, sometimes I cannot follow the instructor quite well, so I think the instructor should convey his ideas and lectures in a clearer way that students who have not been exposed to this area and have no idea or basic knowledge about it can understand more easily.
The course is aimed at those with little stats background, but is also appropriate for advanced students.
very good
strength: very helpful for the future work that I would like to do, content is interesting.
Really learnt something
This was a great course. A strength is the instructor's extensive knowledge in the area. The course could be improved with a bit more clearly stated exam questions.

This was a good class because it exposed me to things that I would never have known. The instructor has knowledge beyond that of a textbook, and he teaches using real life examples, which really adds to the class. This might actually be considered a small weakness as well, since it is hard to reconcile any differences between lecture notes and the textbook.
The articles the professor assigned us is a really good exposure as a preparation for future research work. The course is indeed helpful as a start of clinical trial research learning.

Overall, I thought this was an excellent course. I loved the interesting stories that the professor was able to give that went along with the principles he was teaching throughout the semester. The mid-term and final were both a bit tough, but I do not think there were any glaring weaknesses. A little more practice (in the form of graded homework) calculating K-M by hand might have been useful going into the final.
The professor gives us a lot of examples in class, which is very helpful. If he adds a little more theoretical explanations, this class would be excellent.
Excellent
The course was very helpful in introducing students to clinical trials. It would've been morehelful if the lecture slides were in more detail.

strengths: Dr Makuch offers a wealth of experience, his stories help to fixate in our memories the concepts he talks about.He is trying to involve the students and maintains the level of attention quite high during his lectures.I was particularly touched by the personal approach and his taking us out for a gathering, he is definitely a superbright and kind man!I also liked the choice of readings: both the textbook and the articles were extremely helpful.

Strengths - It's great to hear real world examples from a professor who clearly has a lot of experience in the field. The class dinner was also great.Weaknesses - It might be helpful to have more experience with quantitative problems in the homework

this course is relevant to regulatory affairs track students, however, I would recommend it only to second year students because the second half of the course if very heavy in linear regression methods.
good

Overall, the course is very well structured and it was fun taking it. The major strengths is the concrete delivery of quantitative tools. At the same time, this is the course's major weakness. For example, one lecture introduced concepts of linear algebra which seemed extremely powerful. Yet, the concepts were only touched instead of explored in further detail. Since the course is, overall, quite quantitative, it might make sense to require a certain level of math entry skills. This suggestion applies, perhaps, to a few other courses at YSPH.

I really enjoyed the course, I think it was a good combination of some basic statistics tools (survival analysis, sample size calculation) and practical clinical trials concepts. I would highly recommend it to both masters and doctorate level students.
Great class! Sometimes difficult to get the take away from lectures but great course overall.
Overall, the course was well structured. I liked learning sample size calculations and survival analysis.
very useful for epidemiological research. can use the concept in drug study into Epi research design.
Overall, I enjoyed Clinical Trials. It provided a good basic overview of the issues that arise when developing and conducting clinical trials.
Survey course of what was needed in clinical trials. Weakness was that I did not feel prepared for the exams since the homeworks did not prepare us.
The overview and the topics covered was great. The final exam included some of the materials that was not covered during the lectures. TA was very helpful.
The course was very good overall. I do wish it was more focused on the statistical analysis rather than the planning of the trials.

This was a great course. It has many practical applications, and the material is very interesting. The book selected does a great job of synthesizing the material and I still use it as a reference as I design research projects. Overall, the course was intellectually stimulating, and provided important practical skills that if applied correctly will save future researches time and effort. This course teaches you to foresee research design problems and correct them before they become a problem.

The lecture topics were very relevant and interesting. The notes will be useful tools to have for future classes and research projects. I also found the homework to be helpful for practicing the skills we learned in class.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Robert Makuch  inspiring, kind and bright
Instructor: Robert Makuch  very good! I love Professor Makuch.

Instructor: Robert Makuch  Dr. Makuch is a good guy and knows his stuff but the class could really benefit from better organization. Some topics, like survival analysis, are taught in pieces and repeated over some 5 different lectures. Also I appreciate hearing about his experiences but all the storytelling can be very distracting.
Instructor: Robert Makuch  good
Instructor: Robert Makuch  He is great. Explained the important points in detail, emphasized the important subjects.
Instructor: Robert Makuch  strength: very niceweakness: his way of teaching is not very engaging
Instructor: Robert Makuch  He did a good job of engaging the class. Did have a tendency to go on tangents sometimes.
Instructor: Robert Makuch  Very knowledgeable and responsive to students.

Instructor: Robert Makuch  Answered in Question 6. I hope Prof. Makuch can focus more on the basic ideas and principles in clinical trials, instead of going into details some very complicated trial examples, so that beginning learners in this area can understand and follow easily. Also, I hope Prof. Makuch can write the powerprint in a more detailed and clear way.
Instructor: Robert Makuch  Dr. Makuch is obviously an experienced professor. He has a good sense of humor, is approachable, and is always prepared for lecture.
Instructor: Robert Makuch  very good
Instructor: Robert Makuch  He is a good instructor with a unique teaching style. I like the fact that he brings his work experience into the course.
Instructor: Robert Makuch  a person who has lots of fun

Instructor: Robert Makuch  Overall, the instructor was good. However, I wished that the instructor posts the homework and readings a week before they were due. I had to prioritize my classwork, so knowing the homework and reading assignments one week ahead of when they were due would be have been helpful to me.Also, for one of the final exam questions, an equation was given in class that was necessary to use on one of the final exam questions. The equation should have been introduced in lecture notes and/or be asked on a homework question so that students are aware of the equation. It was unfair to test the students on an equation that was not discussed in lecture notes and/or introduced in the homework. The equation was only given at the last day of class and it was written on the board.
Instructor: Robert Makuch  Dr. Makuch was great-he provided relevant examples for each topic.
Instructor: Robert Makuch  professor Robert Makuch is great professional
Instructor: Robert Makuch  He is very knowledgable in this field and always had an applicable answer for any questions asked. He was reasonable in his expectations of the students.
Instructor: Robert Makuch  It would be better if the slides could include more details.

Instructor: Robert Makuch  Terrific instructor! Kept the class interesting and fun. I actually really appreciated the human side he was been able to bring to this (what some might have assumed to be dry) material throughout the semester.

Instructor: Robert Makuch  Patience, ability to relate class materials to real-life scenariosweakness: not very good in explaining. He tries really hard to make it clear. But I feel I do not understand it much.
Instructor: Robert Makuch  He was an expert in the field and it was very interesting to listen to his lectures.
Instructor: Robert Makuch  see above-
Instructor: Robert Makuch  Same as above

Instructor: Robert Makuch  Dr. Makuch is one of the best professors in our school. Dr. Makuch knows how to teach in a way that makes learning something more than an academic task, he knows how to make the material seem relevant and applicable in the field and not just something that lives in textbooks. I enjoy his stories about working in the NIH and how he is able to connect them to the material that he is teaching, it make the point that what we learn is actually something that is useful to us and not just something that we have to learn.

Instructor: Robert Makuch  Very nice instructor, very experienced and knowledgeable of clinical trials. However, it would be better if the lecture layout is more systematic. For those who know little about clinical trial, some concepts and basic biostats knowledge should be explained in the lecture.
Instructor: Robert Makuch  good
Instructor: Robert Makuch  The professor is very nice and eager to help.

Instructor: Robert Makuch  The instructor is very experienced and delivers the course in a structured and thoughtful manner. His examples from industry and really enriching and actually quite unique compared to other courses as YSPH. This real life course delivery is clearly the greatest strength.Probably, the major weakness is his unavailability at times to ask questions or discuss the course - he seems like a very busy man.

Instructor: Robert Makuch  I think Dr. Makuch is knowledgeable about the topic and was always eager to answer students questions in class. I also enjoyed the guest lecturers we had throughout the semester, including our TA Amanda.
Instructor: Robert Makuch  Great professor!
Instructor: Robert Makuch  Professor MaKuch is very knowledgeable about the course. He makes sure people understand the concepts he is teaching.
Instructor: Robert Makuch  Nice, clear, passionate. Can convey complicated concept to student in a easily understandable way. very knowledgable
Instructor: Robert Makuch  Dr. Makuch really wanted students to learn. It was apparent that he had a lot of experience working in the field and was therefore able to provide a lot of examples.
Instructor: Robert Makuch  The instructor was great. Thorough explanation would help to engage students during the lectures, and more case studies would help.

Instructor: Robert Makuch  Professor Makuch taught the course very well. He was well prepared for lectures and I always got a lot out of each lecture. The class slides were helpful. The only weakness was that he often would tell stories and get off on tangents in class. Sometimes the stories were helpful to understand the material and I generally enjoyed them, but often they were not.

Instructor: Robert Makuch  Professor Makuch is really an expert. His experience in the field spans several decades as well as several continents. He is very knowledgable and personable. He is always ready to provide advice or answer questions. His teaching style is very straightforward, and he often interlaces his lectures with personal experiences that illustrate the point he is trying to make. Very few instructors can bring together his level of expertise and knowledge and combine it with an exceptional teaching style that is straightforward without oversimplifying the material. And yet fewer can share the personal experiences he has had in the field. Overall, I enjoyed Professor Makuch's course.

Instructor: Robert Makuch  Professor Makuch is very knowledgeable about study design and analysis of clinical trial data. He very clearly answered questions. I also enjoyed having guest lecturers come to talk about different trial designs and analyses.

good

good at gradingweakness: not very proactive
She was good.
Since there were no sections, I had little interaction with the TA. She graded homework in a timely manner and offered helpful feedback.
TA performswell.
Amanda was a great TA. She was responsive, confident, and professional. Her lecture was well-spoken, and her English skills are excellent.
good
TA's name: Amanda Qing Zhao.TA is quite responsible, and responsive for questions.
Good
Amanda was a great TA for this course...very helpful.
Amanda was nice and willing to help whenever.
great
I think she did a great job overall. She also did well teaching the class about ways to handle missing data.
TA was kind and helpful
The TA was prompt in returning assignments and responding to emails.
Amanda has a very clear head and is very organized.
TA was very helpful and responsive to e-mails
Amanda was amazing. I'm very helpful for the time she devoted to helping me understand the material.
good
Personally, I had too little interaction to evaluate the TAs.
She was great, responded to questions in a timely manner, was extremely helpful, and always graded our assignments promptly.
Great TF!
She was okay.
Qing Zhao is a excellent TA.Very nice and always ready to help.Very clear in explaining questions with good logic and great patience.
Overall, Amanda was a fine TA. She provided notes on the homework and was approachable during office hours.
TA was very helpful.

Amanda was a good TA. She was very timely with her class announcements and homework solutions. She taught one of the lectures very well, the only suggestion I would make is to make the slides less wordy.

The TA was dedicated, hard working, and did a great job providing feedback on work. She made herself available for answering questions. I highly recommend going to her office hours as she demonstrates a keen understanding for the material, and does a great job of explaining it by deconstructing it and building it up.

Qing Zhao (Amanda)Amanda's lecture on missing data was interesting and well-presented. Her lecture notes were very clear. I also appreciated her effort in reviewing and commenting on our homework assignments, even though they were not officially graded. She also regularly posted hints and clarifications on the classesv2 website.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: helpful. recommend.
I strongly recommend it. Very helpful You could learn a lot from it.
This course is not difficult at all. Lectures are a lot longer than they need to be due to quite a bit of storytelling.
useful

A must. I highly recommend this course, as clinical trials are a vital part of the medical practice. During the course you learn real life examples and after this course your point of view to clinical trials changes substantially. Articles start to make sense, you can analyze and criticize the articles in detail. In conclusion, this course is an excellent learning experience.
it's fine if one wants to learn more about clinical trial design
Great class, learned a lot. Highly recommend.

A basic overview of topics related to conducting and evaluating clinical trials. Course material was not heavily waited in statistical theory; it provided a surface level understanding of the statistics used in clinical trial data analysis.
Answered in Question 6.
I have already recommended this course to my fellow students.
yes, I would recommend it.
The course gives you a overview of the conduct and design of clinical trials. I would recommend this course to students.
Recommended

The class allows one to be familiarize with the basic construction of clinical trials. If a student is interested in conducting or gaining understanding of how one goes about determining the sample size for various types of clinical trials, then this course would be for him/her.
Lots of reading, but great in terms of the material you learn and learning from the experience of the professor.
Actually, the fellow should be at least prepared and have practiced on statistic work
This is a good introductory class. I would recommend it to another student because it gives a very good, basic understanding of related topics.
yes this is a good course, everyone loves it!
This is a very good course to intruduce clinical trials and the use of longitudinal data analysis. I think nearly every student should take it.
If you want to learn something about clinical trial, take this class!

I heard from other students that some of the material is covered in other classes. So I will only talk from my perspective as an AP student. I thought the covered conceptswere incredibly useful for me as a budding physician researcher. I just wish we had even more practice in applying those concepts in the clinical world.
I feel that this course is helpful to get a general idea of what clinical trials are and of how strong an impact regulatory agencies have on the execution of a clinical trial

I would recommend this to students in the regulatory affairs track, however, I also realize that clinical trials is not something every student is interested in so I would not tell everyone that this is a course that they should take.
Good course.It seems that the final exam has went beyond what we have learnt in class. Hope the final is consistent with our homework.
good
Yes. Learn something and not a lot of workload.

I would recommend this course to another student. Even if one isn't interested in conducting clinical trials as a career, the understanding of all the planning and analyses that goes into them is very valuable.
The course is great: it provides students with quantitative skills, has great guest lectures, and seems pretty close to real life work. I would recommend this course to a fellow student.
Good class. Sometimes the prof goes on a tangent with lectures but straight forward.
I would recommend this course
yes , useful for future study design.
This is a great course for those interested in a career in pharmaceuticals or medicine.
I would recommend it to another student.

This course was a good introduction to the implications of the design of clinical trials and the analysis of data from clinical trials. I would recommend this course to another student if they are looking to learn about the challenges of the planning and implementation of clinical trials as a well as a basic understanding of survival analysis and longitudinal data analysis.
Great course. If you are interested in research, you should take this course. The skills and knowledge gained through this course will serve you well in your future career as a researcher.

I would recommend this course. It links concepts I have learned in past epidemiology and biostatistics classes. The sample size and power calculations are incredibly helpful and relevant skills to have.
